Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Expanded Group Affiliation, Trust and Prosociality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
UC Santa Barbara doctoral candidate Anne Pisor, supervised by Dr. Michael Gurven, will undertake research on how cooperative intent and trust toward out-group members change as individuals strategically shift their group memberships. Trust and cooperation across groups are critical to cross-population collaboration, required for the success of internationally funded development projects such as roads and dams, yet previous research has demonstrated that such sentiment is difficult to achieve in culturally, ethnically, and linguistically diverse social contexts. Further, some investigators have found that trust of and cooperation towards out-group members increases with integration to national society and economies, while others have found that it declines. Motivated by research from across the social sciences, this project will investigate whether strategic shifts in group membership are the missing variable in work connecting cooperation and trust to socioeconomic integration. The researchers predict that it is not exposure to out-groups, but an individual's valuation of these groups and their members, that changes these sentiments.

This project will employ ethnographically-informed interviews, economic experiments, and participant observation to explore this prediction with three populations of horticulturalists from the Bolivian lowlands. These populations were selected because they differ both across households and across communities in their degree of socioeconomic integration. Bolivia is an ideal place to conduct this research as it is both ethno-linguistically diverse and undergoing rapid socioeconomic change. However, the methods used are designed such that they can be modified for other contexts. Because of the systematic approach of this project and its integrative nature, results will be of broad interest both across the social sciences and outside of academia. Measuring the scope of group affiliation and its relationship to cooperation and trust may improve the ability of international organizations to match development projects to communities where collective action is likely to take place.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drawing on research from across the social sciences, this project examined the factors that affect when people make friends with out-group members, in particular whether their access to resources and existing connections impact when they consider out-group friendships. To explore out-group relationships in a context where the importance of market resources, and thus the importance of out-group relationships, varied, the co-PI conducted this research among three populations of horticulturalists in lowland Bolivia. Each participant was given the opportunity to give money non-anonymously to strangers from ethnic groups or religious groups with whom she did not identify. A participant was more likely to be generous to out-group strangers when she had less subjective access to money and market resources, but had lived in a larger number of cities or towns – even independent of aspects of her personality (like Extraversion) that might motivate out-group contact. Further, she was more likely to send money to out-group members when she had existing friends or family who helped with cooperative harvesting of crops. However, the role of discrimination in shaping between-group relationships is not to be underestimated: members of one population gave significantly less to out-group members the more market items they owned; ethnographic evidence suggests that discrimination, which is often leveled at this population, may be the cause.

               This project is making wide impacts on the social science literature on intergroup relationships. The first article conveying these results is in press at Nature Scientific Reports, a journal with broad readership. One goal of this project was to generate a mixed methods approach to intergroup relationships with direct applications to international development work; thus far, the project has spurred two collaborations which will generate applications. The co-PI will be further refining this applied approach with a team of field researchers at the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. During the course of this project, the co-PI has contributed to the development of human resources in rural Bolivia. At community members’ requests, she conducted English classes for children and adults in five of the seven study communities; this is especially crucial help as Bolivian students are required to learn English, but most Bolivian teachers cannot speak it. Two of the seven communities also requested bilingual English-Spanish books for schoolchildren, and three communities requested notebooks and pencils for every local student, all of which she provided thanks to the support of the NSF. With the support of the co-PI, a Bolivian research assistant and an American undergraduate research assistant also honed their experimentation skills, which they have used to attain new positions in their respective fields: the Bolivian researcher as a research assistant for another project, and the American student as a lab manager in psychology at a prestigious U.S. university.
